NOTE ON UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION IN UNITED KINGDOM ONJANUARY 7, 1921.The Trade Union figure of unemployment for July, 1914 was 2-8 per cent. The average for the ten years prior to the war, according to Trade Union unem-ployment figures, was 4-7 per cent. A considerable number of workpeople are still on extended^Christmas andNew Year holidays. In the shipbuilding industry a large number of contracts have been cancelled, and the outlook is not promising. Unemployment is increasing in the shipyards on account of the prolongation of the joiners' strike. The position remains practically unchanged in both cotton and woollen textile trades. It is reported from Leicester that there is a possibility of a revival in the boot and shoe industry next month, but it will be a considerable time before conditions in this industry approach the normal. As a result of the fixing of definite prices, improvement is expected in the lace trade, and there are also hopes of an early improvement in the hosiery industry. In South II. EMERGENCY WORK.The Prime Minister made a statement in the House of Commons on the 19th October on the proposals of the Government to provide against unemployment. He outlined schemes for employing a large number of fit ex-Service men in connection with the Housing Programme, on which negotiations with the trade unions were proceeding; and schemes for anticipating a four years' programme for arterial roads in London and in the provinces; whilst at the same time pressing forward with the Ministry of Transports programme of road classification and maintenance grants.On the 21st December the Minister of Labour was able to announce that further measures contemplated by the Government would include: (1) a further endeavour to secure agreement with the building trades for the admission of ex-Service men for whom a training grant would be made; (2) the rapid extension of road construction; (3) the formation of the Unemployment Grants Committee presided over by Viscount St. Davids, to whom a sum of 3,000,000 would be allocated for the purposes of assisting Local Authorities in carrying out approved schemes of relief work other than road making and house building; (4) the amendment of the Unemployment Insurance Act (1920) in order to enable benefit to be paid to persons who have been unemployed since the Act came into operation and were consequently unable to qualify for benefit.ROAD WORK PROGRAMME. Alternative Work at National Factories.Returns supplied by the War Office for the week ending the 1st January, 1921, indicate that the number of men then employed on alternative work at the five Government Industrial establishments at Woolwich, Enfield, Gretna, Queensferry and Lancaster was 2,538, out of a total number employed in the establishments in question of 16,888.(6.) VISCOUNT ST. DAVIDS' COMMITTEE.In accordance with the announcement in the House of Commons on the 21st December, an Unemployment Grants Committee has been appointed under the Chairmanship of Viscount St. Davids to administer a grant of 3,000,000 which had been allocated for the purpose of assisting Local Authorities in carrying out approved schemes of useful work other than roads and housing.Works are approved in those areas only where serious unemployment exists which is not otherwise provided for. Preference is given to ex-Service men. Grants do not exceed 30 per cent, of the wages bill of additional unemployed men engaged, and the works undertaken are such as are approved by the appropriate Government Departments as suitable works of public utility.Up to the 8th January, applications for grants by 16 local authorities in respect of 25 schemes had been sanctioned by the Committee. The total sum allocated under these sanctions was 29,130, and the total number for whom employment will be provided is estimated to be about 2,198 (including men working part time).o
